case_vignette: An 8-year-old African-American boy presents with a 3-day history of fever, pain, and a rash on his trunk! On examination, the patient has several fragile, bullous lesions on his trunk, many of which have eroded, exposing erythematous, annular lesions! The patient is febrile and shaking in the office, and he appears to be in pain! He has no other relevant social or family history and does not take any medications! His mother is very concerned about her son!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a fever, pain, and a rash on my trunk for the past three days.
Can you describe the appearance of the rash?
The rash consists of several fragile, blister-like lesions on my trunk, and many of these blisters have broken open, revealing red, ring-shaped lesions.
Have you experienced this type of rash before, or is this the first occurrence?
This is the first occurrence of this type of rash.
Do you have any known chronic illnesses or are you currently on any medication?
No, I don't have any chronic illnesses and I am not taking any medications.
Do the lesions on your trunk follow a specific nerve path or are they more widespread?
The lesions are more widespread on my trunk.
Have you recently been ill with any infections or had a fever prior to noticing the rash?
Yes, I have had a fever for the past three days along with the rash.
Final Diagnosis: Disseminated Herpes Zoster.
